Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

ALLEGATION:
Youth A was AWOL from Methodist and located by LE. Youth A was uncontrollable,
and aggressive toward himself and LE. LE transported Youth A to the hospital for
an evaluation. LE waited two hours to receive necessary info from Methodist staff.
The facility refused to send a staff person to the hospital to relieve LE.
INVESTIGATION:
Intake
MISACWIS indicated that Police Officer 1 (PO 1) received the information/allegation
he reported from “other law enforcement officers.” Those officers were not identified
in MISACWIS and thus, could not be interviewed.
Interviews
I interviewed Youth A, age 12, jointly with Government Worker 1. He has been at
the facility for nine months. Youth A said he and Youth M went AWOL together and
walked to Walmart on Sunday evening. After that “We found a pole and I started
banging my head on it. The police came. I threw a rock at him and spit on him. I
asked the police to take me to the hospital.” Youth A said Staff 1 stayed with him at
the hospital and was relieved by Staff 2. Youth A was psychiatrically cleared and
returned to Methodist the next day.
Youth A stated he routinely bangs his head when he is upset. He was upset
because he thought “Youth M called the cops on a phone he stole from Walmart.”
Youth A said he feels safe at Methodist but “likes to go off-campus” without
permission.
I interviewed Off-Duty Shift Supervisor (ODSS 1). On Sunday at 8:38pm, he said
he at home eating dinner when he received a call from the police on his personal cell
phone. It is unclear why the police contacted his personal cell.
On the date of the incident, ODSS 1 said he was not working and was not the
designated on-call supervisor or administrator. “They (police) had collected Youth M
and A and they were on 7 Mile and Inkster Road (in Livonia). He wanted Methodist
to send someone to get both kids at that location. At 8:42pm, while enroute to the
campus, ODSS 1 said “I called Livonia Police Department and asked them to
transport the kids back to Methodist (instead of Methodist staff picking them up).
First the officer refused, then he agreed but notified me he would be making a
complaint against Methodist. Youth M was dropped off at Methodist and the police
took Youth A to the hospital. At 9:12pm, I dispatched Staff 1 to the hospital. At
9:14pm, I called him (police) to give him Staff 1’s name.” At 11pm, ODSS 1 said he
and Staff 2 went to the hospital. “I wanted to check on Youth A who was sleeping.”
3

Staff 2 remained with Youth A and Staff 1 went home. ODSS 1 denied he or anyone
at Methodist ever refused to pick the youths up in Livonia or send a staff person to
supervise Youth A at the hospital.
I interviewed On-Call Administrator 1 (OCA 1) jointly with Government Worker 1.
He said he was “on-call” that evening. ODSS 1 contacted OCA 1 after the police
called ODSS 1 at home. ODSS 1 and OCA 1 coordinated with the police by phone
and assigned Staff 1 to go supervise Youth A at the hospital. According to ODSS 1,
Staff 1 was dispatched to the hospital approximately 30 minutes after he received
the initial call from police.
I interviewed Acting Supervisor 1 (AS 1) jointly with Government Worker 1. AS 1‘s
official title is Methodist’s Director of Children’s Services. Director of Children’s
Services is not a position regulated by DCWL, but Supervisor of Direct Care
Workers is. AS 1 said the afternoon shift supervisor called off on 10/10/21 so she
covered his shift and was physically present on campus until 8pm.
Employee File
I reviewed AS 1’s resume. Per licensing Rule 400.4120, AS 1 has worked in a child
caring institution for at least two years and is qualified to supervise direct care
workers.
According to Acting Chief Administrator 1 (ACA 1), a shift supervisor typically
works until 11pm. Rather than stay until 11pm, AS 1 told me she checked that the
cottages were quiet, forwarded the calls to OCA 1 and left the campus around 8pm.
Youths A and M had gone AWOL at 5:45pm and were still missing when AS 1 left
the campus for the night.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
4

ANALYSIS: There is no evidence to support that Methodist refused to send
a staff person to the hospital as alleged, as Staff 1 and Staff 2
were both there to supervise Youth A. According to ODSS 1,
Methodist did not refuse to pick up the youths from 7 mile and
Inkster Rd. ODSS 1 said he merely asked police officers if they
could transport the children back to the facility. After the police
agreed, they told ODSS 1 that they would be filing a complaint.
There is a violation however, as Methodist is required to have a
sufficient number of supervisors on duty and present at the
facility. On 10/10/21. AS 1 went home leaving the campus
unsupervised from 8pm - 11pm. ODSS 1 responded to a call
from police on his personal cell phone. He was not “on-call” at
the time but went to campus anyway and handled the situation
on his scheduled day off.
CONSULTATION
Methodist is an open campus for abuse/neglect wards. The exit
doors in the cottages are not secure and do not prevent children
from leaving. Further, staff are not permitted to physically
restrain children to prevent them from leaving. Youth at high
risk for truancy may be better served if placed in a secure
facility.
That said, the local police are clearly frustrated by the number of
AWOLs and calls to intervene with Methodist youth. It is
strongly recommended that Methodist’s Administration meet
with the local police to improve their relationship with community
partners.
Based on the numbers and type of children Methodist serves,
the physical presence of at least one supervisor is crucial on all
three shifts.
It is also strongly recommended that Methodist ensures the local
police know how to contact the supervisor on campus or the on-
call administrator outside of normal business hours.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Any staff person, including Directors and Administrators, who
cover a vacant DCWL-regulated position such as Supervisor of
Direct Care Staff must also qualify and be trained for that
position per the licensing rules.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
